151272753.review:
Have you ever thought, "You know what's missing in my life? A rebellious turnip with a penchant for tax evasion." Well, fear not, because Turnip Boy is here to fill that oddly specific void in your gaming experience!

From the moment I booted up Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion, I knew I was in for a wild ride. The game's plot is as absurd as it sounds—our hero, Turnip Boy, is slapped with a hefty tax bill, and instead of selling his precious turnip farm to pay off the debt like a responsible vegetable, he decides to embark on a mission to commit tax evasion. Forget Mario saving princesses; Turnip Boy is here to save his hard-earned turnips from the IRS!

The gameplay is a delightful mix of puzzles, quirky characters, and turnip-based chaos. I never thought I'd see the day when solving tax-related puzzles would be so entertaining. From navigating bureaucratic mazes to outsmarting IRS agents with turnip disguises, every moment is a hilarious adventure. The controls are intuitive, and the graphics are charmingly pixelated, giving the game a nostalgic feel that pairs perfectly with its absurd premise.

One of the highlights is the diverse cast of characters Turnip Boy encounters on his tax-evading journey. From a chill mushroom landlord who just wants his rent in mushrooms to a caffeine-fueled coffee cup, each character brings a unique flavor to the game. The witty dialogue had me laughing out loud more times than I'd like to admit, and the writing is so on point that even the tax documents have personality.

The soundtrack deserves a special mention, too. It's a catchy blend of tunes that perfectly complements the game's quirky atmosphere. I found myself humming along as I guided Turnip Boy through his unconventional escapades.

Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is more than just a game; it's a hilarious commentary on the absurdities of bureaucracy and taxation. It's a reminder that sometimes, you just have to laugh in the face of impending financial doom. So, if you're looking for a game that combines clever puzzles, charming characters, and turnip-fueled shenanigans, look no further. Turnip Boy has got your back, and he's ready to make tax evasion the most fun you've ever had!

150484544.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a game whose name is far more interesting than the actual game itself.

The game is primarily a combination of a fetch-a-thon with a basic top-down primitive Zelda-esque game mechanics. The problem is, these mechanics are extremely basic and not very fun. Turnip Boy simply isn’t very fun to control, the enemies are all extremely simple, and there’s no particularly interesting fighting mechanics – you just swipe at things with your sword, and none of the things in question have particularly interesting fighting abilities. The original NES Zelda is a greatly superior game to this in terms of gameplay. And the fetch quests (which make up virtually the whole game) are inane and often require a bunch of backtracking back and forth across areas you’ve already explored.

The story is jokey and not very interesting; it isn’t designed to make you care about any of the characters, everyone is terrible, and the jokes rarely land. While it tries to go with some Deep Lore as it goes on, it’s nothing particularly interesting or innovative, and doesn’t do anything to rescue the game world or narrative.

The art in the game is very basic – it is not terrible, but it is not beautiful, and doesn’t really engage me at all. Games can have simple art (like Chicory: A Colorful Tale) while still looking really good; this game doesn’t accomplish that.

This game is only about three hours long, but the time I spent playing it was nevertheless far more than it deserved. There was really nothing here to make me feel like the time I invested was worthwhile.

148792934.review:
It's a great, great game. Creative, silly, fun, well designed, accessible, relatively short, but as long as it needs to be; I loved it.

The game presents itself as a "joke" game but it's far from being that, sure there's humor, but there's also a really good game underneath it all; the characters and dialogs are well written and enjoyable, the upgrades and hats you collect as you progress feel significant, and overall, the entire game is filled with charm and done with care and love.

The combat is really easy for the most part, but they figure out ways to make it engaging and satisfying; there are a couple of bosses -specially near the end-, that got fairly tough, but there are, thankfully, accessibility settings to increase the damage and even make you invulnerable if you want to, I personally pushed through, but I appreciate that -like the developer mentions in the submenu of these options-, the game is designed to be enjoyed by "as many people as possible". I like that attitude.

The game also unlocks a completely new and different mode at the end of the game that completely changes the entirety of the experience, but you can't skip the credits... which normally I would find a bit aggrandizing and annoying, but here it's done to communicate a genuine thanks to the players and the people behind the game, either directly or indirectly.

148612599.review:
You know, I thought I would like this game more than I actually did. That's not exactly the negative statement it sounds like.

It's a short, charming little adventure to be sure, that manages to start at an idyllic setting, dips down into an intriguing horrific backstory, and then climbs back up to a silly and outrageous climax. A journey accompanied by the many...let's say [i]heartful[/i] characters that inhabit its world.

It's a rather linear experience, mostly comprised of go to place and do/grab thing objectives--even the puzzles are rather straightforward, and can be easily intuited within the time it takes to, say, walk from the room's entrance to the first part of the puzzle, so if you're looking to be actually challenged, then this game might not be for you, but if you're just looking for a comfy, casual little adventure, then look no further. There's also not an insignificant amount of backtracking, but thankfully the world itself is pretty small, so it's only a considerable amount of backtracking within the game's scope.

As for why I didn't like it as much as I thought I would...I guess it's just personal taste. See, even though the characters are all these cartoony plant lives, they openly talk about committing crimes and being general vandals and the like. I've never been a fan of those cutesy-aesthetics-meets-dark-and-gritty-subjects schticks. Also memes. Not a fan. There's one character who is a JoJo reference for the sake of having a JoJo reference. That said, that was mostly early on in the story; I ended up really liking the mystery of how these plant lives came to be, woven into the actual main plot of you fetching stuff for the mayor.

Oh, and once you beat the game, you unlock a roguelike mode that earns you tickets that you can buy hats with. I only tried it to get the last three achievements as the combat gameplay isn't exactly deep, but it's worth mentioning. Thankfully those hats aren't required for the "get all hats" achievement.

For six bucks, I'd say the game's totally worth it.

Feels like a flash game. Especially for 2.3 hours. 

"Avoid paying taxes" not sure that ever happened

"Solve plantasitic puzzles" if brushing your teeth is a puzzle then these are your level of difficulty. Furthermore, by the end of the game, the riddles even referenced how bad they were. 

"Harvest crops" broadly speaking this is the best part of the game. However you are given a very neat "portal pot" to use a couple of times in the dungeon you acquire it and never need it again despite it being the only fun part. 

"Battle massive beasts" Turnip boy occupies 1 square and bosses are 4 squares. Dodge boss into wall and mash attack until dead. You will never suffer enough damage to die unless you try to die as bosses will suffer knockback and do very little actual damage. Even then, every boss fight has multiple spots to collect health. 

Meanwhile, game is arbitrary about what you can rip up. Love letter? Torn up. Letter from long lost son to father? you are playing postman back and forth for these 2 potatoes. Turnip tears up far more important documents throughout the game but for some reason is willing to be postman for these 2? Love letter guy was on the same screen as his crush but you rip that right up in front of him. Then you got Tots having me play Pony Express after I told you his dad is still alive? Where did the letter come from so fast? Why doesn't he believe me and just go see his dad? Guess what Pops has for you when you deliver him the letter? Another letter THAT YOU CANNOT RIP UP!? "Oh and please come back for a reward after you deliver this to my son" No sir, screw you, I am not going back to see your Spud and you can shove your cosmetic hat. I hope you remain estranged instead of placing your faith in a Turnip who has been notoriously tearing up every paper product I have encountered.

Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a great game, especially for the price.  It is short, sweet, silly, and simple.  However, it has its flaws.

Pros
 - Charming art style
 - Fun, silly dialog
 - Simple, yet funny and interesting story (you are committing tax evasion as a turnip)
 - A variety of enemies, none of which really felt repetitive
 - Fun bosses
 - Interesting collectibles

Cons

146899934.review:
[h1] "Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion: A Veggie-Fueled, Hilarious Adventure" [/h1]

You ever judge a book by its cover? Well, I judged a game by its name, and I have no regrets. "Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion" - who could resist that title? But let me tell you, this quirky adventure is so much more than tax dodging vegetables.

First off, the game's art style is as sweet as candy, with colorful, cartoonish characters that scream "wholesome." But don't be fooled - this game's humor is as edgy as it gets. It's like an adorable façade masking a dark internet meme addiction.

Now, humor is subjective, and I have strong feelings about it. American stand-up comedy? Not my cup of tea. So when a game doesn't even label itself as a comedy but has me laughing out loud, that's a surprise.

"Turnip Boy" doesn't shove its jokes down your throat. Instead, it's all in the game's DNA. Picture this: Every character is a fruit or veggie with charming, clever designs. Turnip Boy himself has a hilarious wobbly walk that adds to the charm. And the first boss? A giant pig king that turns into bacon when defeated. Need I say more?

But where "Turnip Boy" truly shines is in its writing. It's got that internet vibe, self-aware and witty. A streamer blocking your path until you buy them a sandwich? Yep. A quest to collect rent that ends in, well, murder? You bet. Turnip Boy tearing up every piece of paper handed to him, not just tax documents? Classic.

The game pokes fun at pop culture tropes and references various memes, but you don't need a PhD in internet culture to enjoy it. The puzzles are straightforward, and the story keeps you engaged. Plus, the game's length is just right – enough to satisfy your gaming craving without dragging on.

Now, let's talk about the dungeons. They're like mini-Zelda adventures with clever puzzles. You gather tools, like a watering can and boots, to solve challenges. It's satisfying to figure out how to use these tools together to progress.

But, and there's a but, boss fights can be a real pain. The combat system feels clumsy, especially during these battles. It's like trying to dance but tripping over your own feet. The dodge move is funny, but it's too slow to be useful. It's as if they sacrificed practicality for the joke.

Despite the hiccups, "Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion" is a must-play. It's a weird and hilarious adventure with a killer soundtrack. A very fun game that'll definitely leave you feeling warm once you beat it.

It's a fun and short Zelda-lite adventure with basic melee combat, a few simple bosses, some basic puzzles and one riddle, plus side quests for extra collectables like documents to shred and fancy hats. Took me 3.6 hours to get all of the collectable documents and finish the side quests, and I was going fairly slowly.

The main notable thing about the game is the cute chibi pixel graphics and how they're used to flesh out a interesting fantasy sentient vegetable world full of simple-minded vegetables (you can tell that they're simple-minded because they embrace internet slang and unoriginal memes) who inherited a recovering post-apocalyptic landscape that was once plagued by nuclear warfare, much like Adventure Time's setting.

I really like the unique background setting, and I'm looking forward to the sequel where Turnip Boy is planning on shooting up a bank, plus lore to go with the sequel as well.

145053342.review:
Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Overview:
"Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion" is a quirky and charming indie game developed by Snoozy Kazoo and published by Graffiti Games. This delightful game combines humor, puzzle-solving, and action in a unique pixel-art world. It's a fun and lighthearted experience that's sure to bring a smile to your face.

Story and Characters (4/5):
The game's premise is as bizarre as it sounds: you play as Turnip Boy, a rebellious turnip who, well, commits tax evasion and goes on a wild adventure to clear his name. The humor in the game is offbeat and genuinely funny, with a cast of eccentric characters that add depth to the story. Each character you encounter, from sentient vegetables to corrupt bureaucrats, is memorable and contributes to the game's quirky atmosphere.

Gameplay (4/5):
"Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion" offers a mix of puzzles, combat, and exploration. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring creative thinking rather than brute force to solve. The combat is relatively simple but offers a satisfying challenge as you face off against various garden-themed foes. The game's top-down perspective and controls are intuitive, making it accessible to players of all skill levels.

One standout feature is Turnip Boy's ability to wield different hats, each with unique abilities. These hats add an enjoyable layer of strategy and variety to the gameplay, allowing you to customize your approach to challenges.

Graphics and Art Style (5/5):
The pixel-art visuals in this game are a treat for the eyes. The world is bursting with vibrant colors and detailed environments, and the character designs are charming and full of personality. The art style perfectly matches the game's whimsical tone, creating a visually captivating experience.

Sound and Music (4/5):
The game's sound design is well-executed, with catchy sound effects that enhance the overall experience. The music, composed by Joey Godard, complements the game's whimsy and provides a fitting backdrop to Turnip Boy's adventures. While not the most memorable soundtrack, it certainly adds to the game's charm.

Replayability (3/5):
"Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion" is relatively short, which might disappoint players looking for a longer gaming experience. However, it compensates for this with a New Game+ mode and a range of collectibles and secrets to discover. While not the most replayable game, completionists will find plenty to do.

Conclusion:
"Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion" is a delightful and hilarious indie gem that doesn't take itself too seriously. It offers a unique blend of humor, puzzles, and action in a charming pixel-art world. While it might not be the longest game, its memorable characters, whimsical story, and enjoyable gameplay make it a worthwhile addition to any gamer's library. If you're in the mood for a lighthearted adventure that's sure to bring a smile to your face, don't evade the opportunity to play Turnip Boy's wacky adventure.

144989363.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is an action-adventure game where you play as an anthropomorphic turnip known as Turnip Boy and guide him through an adventure resulting from him evading his taxes.

The story is pretty straightforward. Turnip Boy commits tax evasion and then needs to figure out how to get his greenhouse back due to Mayor Onion taking it as collateral. In order to do this, Mayor Onion tasks Turnip Boy to do a variety of tasks for him. It is one of those games where one quest leads to another quest, and the entire story centers around the various story points you see while completing these quests. It certainly isn't a bad way to tell a story, and this game puts a bunch of personality into each scenario you find yourself in. The overarching story, once you complete all the tasks, is also pretty ridiculous, funny, and downright enjoyable. 

The gameplay is quite standard. It certainly isn't as good as the story, but it acts as a nice vessel for the story's delivery. I don't know if there is a specific category to describe the gameplay, but if you played or seen any of the older Zelda games, then you know what the gameplay is like. However, the stakes are very low in this game, as you will likely never die while playing a majority of the game. Even with the boss fights, there is likely only one or two that will give you much difficulty. However, past the main game, there is a "roguelike" section where you travel through train carts battling enemies. That piece of content can get a bit difficult after a while, but it's entirely optional. 

The graphics are very good. They are simple, stylistic, and fairly unique to the game. The sprite work is well done, and I also find it to be quite recognizable outside of the game. If I'm being honest, it's one of the reasons I even had an interest in the game, apart from the title and concept of the game alone. 

The music and sound design, in my opinion, is one of the weakest parts of the game. However, that doesn't mean it is bad. It is certainly well done, but I just didn't like it as much as the other aspects of the game.

Overall, I think this game is an absolute gem. It's packed with humor, twists, good concepts, cute graphics, and more. I highly recommend giving this game a try!

144519053.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion delivers on its premise in the first scene, where you rip up a notice of your tax being due. Sadly, the gameplay that follows doesn't consist of shootouts with the IRS, but it's still pretty good. 

The gameplay can broadly be split into two halves - combat rooms, and puzzles. The former are dungeon-crawler-esque and see you taking on various herbivorous creatures, typically culminating in a boss fight (which are pretty good). The latter are like if the strength puzzles from Pokémon weren't designed so that babies can complete them. Not mega challenging, but also pretty good.

All of this takes place in a top-down overworld where you perform fetch quests for various NPCs to earn rewards and progress the story. The dialogue is genuinely funny, so these interactions are fun, and as a result these quests never feel too much like a chore.

The pixelart style works well, and all the sprites are great. The soundtrack goes far harder than it has any right to (except for the credits song, which I didn't like at all), and the secret final boss fight is hilarious. There's also a roguelike mode, for some reason. I didn't go super deep with it as I didn't feel the combat system warranted it, and the enemy scaling seems to work in such a way where you eventually just get OHKOed, but it's there.

Overall, while it wasn't a masterpiece that blew me away, I don't have any major gripes with it. It's a polished game with a good atmosphere, and it's genuinely funny. Great way to kill a few hours. Only a few, though - it is a very short game, especially for its asking price. 

7/10 - This is a cute little game that, while it's not going to win any awards for depth, provides a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

142310289.review:
I got the game on sale so I'm glad I didn't pay full price for it. I think it's a cute game as a concept, and I did like the storyline of Matt & Liz which gave the supposedly silly & lighthearted game a more dark undertone. But overall, I wasn't really satisfied with it because:

1) The game is too short. It takes too little time to complete the story, and once you do, there's not much else to do other than challenge the limitless train. And even that gets boring because it's the same 4 bosses over and over again, just powered up each time.

2) The mechanics, especially for combat. You have a "trip" button which is basically your way to dash/dodge attacks, but it is so annoying because the range is short, and you can't stack dodges as you have to wait for Turnip Boy to get up after he has tripped. You run into the same problem when you're walking around and want to dash (because the walking speed is pretty slow and there are no sprint options) but you have to wait after each trip. The attack is also just one hit with your weapon (sword/shovel), so it does not require you to learn and get better at it as there are no combos to master or strategies you can apply to your attack. Controlling where exactly to place the petalportal is difficult, and switching between equippable items is inconvenient. 

3) Gameplay. It's basically a lot of NPCs needing you to fetch them something, and they basically spell out what it is they need and how you will get it, so there's not even any puzzle solving or thinking that you have to do. I think the only quest I can even consider a puzzle was the graveyard one. I realize the spelling out is meant to be humorous (such as when it's like "You're doomed, not even talking to Old Man Lemon will help you now!"), but the jokes often fell flat for me. Also, the walking back and forth between the same regions gets repetitive, and it's especially tedious because there is no map in the game.

4) The Tone. I'm sorry, but I really did not care for the "I can has cheeseburger" type of dated humor the dialogues and the interactions had. The characters are super flat and lack personality. I realize they're meant to be caricatures rather than real characters (such as the vain influencer) and that's the joke, but again, the caricatures are nothing I haven't seen before, they're unoriginal and not that funny. It's also a bit difficult to get through the story when I am not just not rooting for Turnip Boy, our main character, but I'm actively annoyed by his destructive actions or apathy. He did not come across as fun and chaotic as the game probably intended for him to, but just irritating and tiresome.

Maybe I'm critiquing too harshly what is meant to be a quick, lighthearted, and fun game - but for the price it is originally being sold for, I expect there to be more engaging content.

141237347.review:
---This is a slightly edited version of a YouTube video review I'm making---

[h1] Story[/h1]
With a title like that, you wouldn't necessarily think there'd be a story; but there is. Not a huge or detailed one, but there is one. You're obviously playing as Turnip Boy, a turnip living in a glass house who can only speak in punctuation marks in intervals of three but paying his property tax. Mayor Onion shows and makes Turnip Boy his assistant to go get increasingly questionable items for him so he'd look the other way about his taxes not being paid.

Oh and there's a macaroni who just recites a slightly friendlier version of the navy seal copypasta. The humor is mostly on-point! There are some references to stuff, though not as many as in Henry Stickmin; I don't think that will be topped anytime soon.

Since I'm trying to keep this review spoiler-free I'm gonna leave finding out how you get from collecting fertilizer for Mayor Onion to finding a nuke in a mafia stronghold to you.

[h1] Gameplay[/h1]
You're gonna meet lots of characters, like half of whom will give you side quests. It's not at all required to complete any of them, but if you do, you more often than not at least get a funny line or two you otherwise wouldn't have seen.

You will have some weak enemies to fight every now and then, but be aware that they all respawn if you leave the area and come back. They can only ever drop a heart, so if you're not short on HP, it's not worth to kill them, just trip out of their way. Oh yeah, there's no sprint, but you can trip some distance in the direction you're facing.

There are some puzzles, most of which are quite easy. You use a water can to complete them, later unlocking more items to use in puzzles.

This is the basic gameplay loop: receive quest, get item it wants, go back, repeat. There's nothing necessarily wrong with that, but I'll talk more about it in the Achievements section. You don't really play Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion for the gameplay; you play it for the jokes and achievements. Speaking of achievements:

[h1] Achievement Scope[/h1]
You can 100% the game under 4 hours. It has that going for it, however, it requires SO MUCH backtracking and grinding. The map isn't that big, but it gets much bigger because of the constant backtracking. Of course you have to complete every side quest, and after the game ends, you gotta grind about 50 tickets in the endless bossfight train. That gets quite tedious, but it certainly could have been much worse.

Achievements I think are notable are
- Taxation without Representation - you have to beat the final boss again
- Fashionista - collect all hats, which means grinding and beating all side quests
- ??? - the rarest achievement, you gotta reach a certain point in the endless mode

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
All in all Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a short, humor-filled, laid-back experience. There are of course some cons to that, which you see now on the screen, but it is overall an enjoyable game.

Is it worth it?; you might be asking. Is it worth €12,49 in my opinion? No, I don't think it's worth that much. If it was longer, I'd say it's worth it, but at this length, I'll have to say no. However, on sale it is absolutely worth the money!

What about the score?; you also might be wondering. Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion get a solid 72/100.

Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a very solid and funny experience, and if it's on sale, I absolutely do recommend you pick it up!

140699551.review:
**Recommended only if it's on sale**

Cute game, fun dialogue and premise props up fairly basic gameplay for the game's runtime. 

On the plus side, the combat is fun enough (bar a certain late-game boss) and enemies aren't damage sponges. The puzzles are also pretty intuitive and don't really outstay their welcome. The subtle world-building is immaculate, it's rare to see a game nail the background stuff this well.

On the minus side, first and foremost is the price. Is this a cute game? Yeah. Is it 5$ an hour cute? Absolutely not. I got this through a Humble Bundle, but if I had actually paid 15$ for a game that took 2.8 hours for me to get every achievement I would have been pretty annoyed. I think $7.50 would be a solid price if you love games like this and $5 if you don't.

Price aside, if you want to experience everything there's a LOT of backtracking through areas that don't change at all. I think about 1/3 of my time was spent walking through areas I had already been through and it made me really, REALLY wish for a fast travel system, but given the length of the game that might have been done to prevent refunds.

Aside from those hiccups, the game has so much love put into it. It's really nice to see little indie titles like this actually get published, and it's obvious from the amount of polish and care that the people behind it had fun making it. Avoiding spoiling anything, the credits were really nice. Every game could do with a 'Cats' section.

Took two and a half hours to beat the game, and I'm kinda a completionist,so I didn't just cruise on through.

The game seemed low effort, was optimised ok, music was pretty good, but everything else was not so much. I get that the point of the game was for it to be a stupid game, so I don't feel like I missed the point of the game, but god it was a stupid game and I felt it was a waste of my time. Most of the dialogue was references to memes, one was actually funny (not that it made me laugh, but made me slightly exhale), some had a mediocre execution, and most were just badly executed. Some of the areas you had to go back and forth through and it took a while to get through, which I didn't mind while I was fighting enemies...but when travelling back after, it felt needlessly long and winding. The point of the game was to rip things up, which is fine, I guess it's kinda funny, but it made your character have no personality at all, expect a stupid blob that runs around ripping up things it finds. I felt like this could've been executed so that it was a fun treasure hunt...but it was far from well executed. None of the characters had any personality, nothing about the game was memorable, and I only completed it because I was able to do it in two sittings. I could've finished it in one sitting if I found it interesting enough to play for more than an hour and a half at a time.

I only bought this game because it was in a bundle with another game I wanted, getting the bundle made me pay less than $2 more than if I got the other game by itself....I still think it was a waste of my money, It astonishes me that this game is well reviewed, especially at the price its at. 

I feel bad giving this a bad review, but as it seemed so low effort, I can't imagine the creators would take it to heart.

Every time I play a game like Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion (TBCTE), I'm reminded of just how much I miss 2D Zelda games. Developed by Snoozy Kazoo and released in 2021, this charming, top-down adventure game will hit the spot if you are craving a bit of classic action. You're Turnip Boy, a character who's been caught red-handed for tax evasion and must now make amends by running errands for his town's mayor.

Turnip Boy follows the puzzle-adventure style of classic Zelda titles like A Link's Awakening or A Link to the Past. The gameplay places equal weights into both combat and engaging puzzles. The puzzles, while not overly difficult, are cleverly designed and require some out-of-the-box thinking. By the end, you'll find that every item you've collected has its purpose.

I clocked in at around 2 hours and 75% completion -- which is not bad, but the game definitely feels like it could be longer and left me wanting more. TBCTE does increase its replay value by introducing an NPC who gives you hints about the achievements you're missing after you finish your first run. If you are looking to 100% the game without the use of a guide with all the answers laid out, this will help you with the challenge without major spoilers -- a feature I wish more games had.

Looking forward, I'm excited for the announced sequel, Turnip Boy Robs a Bank. If it's anything like this one, we're in for a treat! I give Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion an 8 out of 10. While the relatively short playtime and less challenging puzzles hold it back from a perfect score, the game's charm, creativity, and nostalgic appeal make it a must-play. It's a title that anyone can enjoy, but if you're a fan of top-down 2D adventure games like me, you should definitely get it.

A cute game that endears itself to the player. The puzzle(s) design, soundtrack, and pacing/flow of the game were the biggest standouts to me. It also surprised me in a couple ways, one of them was story related so I'll leave that as a surprise, and the other was that the gameplay and art style lulled me into a false sense of security so I thought "oh this game is gonna be easy" but as the game went on I had to try more. I know that's the case with almost all games but when I looked at this one, I didn't initially think it'd be the case. 

The only real technical problem I have with the game is that it started crashing on me randomly, after I beat the main game and was doing other stuff. It happened 4 or 5 times in one day and I think it may have to do with my blue light filter app but its still a shame. Besides that I felt that the added roguelike/roguelite mode was anemic and lacking variety as far as they go and this coming from one who went through a big Binding of Isaac phase and similar games during high school. It is a post game, optional mode so I'll go easy on it otherwise I would write an entire essay on its flaws. 

I am interested in the announced sequel that is supposed to be coming out this year. It has an interesting premise and leans more into the roguelite/like direction which I wish them all the best with since its a complex and tricky genre to get right. Anyways, pick up this game, Its cute, its simple, and it doesn't overstay its welcome.

Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a free mobile app that's been dumped on Steam as if it was a real PC game (it's not)... it's here as a paid product, representing a nasty cash grab from greedy mobile devs.  The game is essentially a ripoff of Legend of Zelda (copyright Nintendo 1986) and features extremely similar gameplay.  It's been skinned with a sloppily done mismash of cartoony graphics and pixel "art" with a vegetable/comedy theme.  The mobile app reached middling success with Gen Z and Millennials.  While I am going against the "popular" tide here, it's worth pointing out that, even if there were no other reasons to not recommend this game, it's FREE on mobile app stores but costs money on Steam.  If you want to play this kind of game, if this is the kind of game you really want, stop wasting time and money on gaming PCs and Steam and pick up your mobile phone.

While this is well polished as far as mobile app store apps go, it's not pushing any technical boundaries and isn't designed with PC gamers in mind.

From a technical perspective, as a mobile app, this doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

A choice was made to use obsolete, decades old retro pixel "art" as a substitute for contemporary PC graphics, but the developers couldn't get that right, it looks inauthentic because it's paired with many assets and intersitual graphics that aren't 2D pixel art.  Which means the developers could have done better, but didn't.  The overall visual quality of the game is extremely low as a result of this inexplicably poor decision making.

While there are options to change the resolution for the mobile app, all this does is scale up the simplistic low quality vector art assets used to make the mobile app, which makes little or no difference to the graphics quality.  Without any other substantial graphics tweaks, it's not possible for gamers to improve the mediocre 2D visuals.

There's no mouse support whatsover, perhaps the mobile app developers don't know what they are because they couldn't work out how to plug a mouse into their iPhones.  Regardless this makes navigating the game menus a tedious chore, it's simply not acceptable for mobile apps to be ported so badly to PC. 

Because this is a mobile app, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the iPhones that the mobile app was designed for.  These are unfortunate handicaps and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was an afterthought for the iPhone developers who are to blame for this.  The mobile app is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for mobile phones forces upon a game.  Once more, mobile devs have made gaming worse for everyone.  I didn't spend thousands on building a gaming rig just so I could pretend it's an iPhone.

These technical defects push this mobile app below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to scam PC gamers. On Steam, this is $15 USD, on app stores, it's free. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a [b]COMPLETELY INSANE FIFTEEN BUCKS FOR A FREE MOBILE APP[/b] just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.  This is unacceptable disrespect for PC gamers.  Because this can be played free elsewhere, and because of the other defects, it's impossible to recommend.  Who do they think we are?

Turnip boy lives in a small greenhouse in the center of a lovely place called Veggieville; or he used to live there. Mayor Onion evicts Turnip Boy from his home after failing to pay his taxes and sends him on multiple quests and errands to pay back what is owed. Unfortunately for the Mayor and everyone living in Veggieville, Turnip boy is chaotic neutral and a general menace to society. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2958280784

2-3 hours to complete, I had an absolutely amazing time committing crimes in Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion. The game is extremely cute and well written with a pretty [spoiler]morbid[/spoiler] backstory! The fights are easy and the boss fights can be difficult at first try, but I really liked all the clever game mechanics and every area introduces a new mechanic so the game never got boring. In particular, the OST or background music really is well made and fun to listen to, and there are plenty of hats for Turnip boy to collect. It’s a cute game!

137002124.review:
Relaxing game that doesn't take itself too seriously, it was always a blast start to finish. It's short, moderately easy to 100% on achievements too. 

Surprise surprise, turns out you really are on your way to committing tax evasion and fighting against the corrupt onion mayor. Later we find out that the mayor, Turnip boy's papi and mr. Lemon had history together. Turnip boy helps other veggies around the village, rips apart any tax documents that he finds, collects hats and reads lore with the help of notes and journals. 

Gameplay wise the game behaves like a cartoon Zelda (I dislike these types of comparisons but I'll use them for lack of a better term), I played on the default difficulty and the game was easy especially with health upgrades, the bosses were interesting, however the game has plenty of accessibility options that help the player tweak their game experience. 
I loved the writing, there's many Easter eggs from pop culture and quirky characters. Heck, you're even going to get a portal gun and implement it into your rotation either to solve easy puzzles or fight bosses. 

If you have it from a bundle try it, if not maybe wait for a sale.

I don't mind that the whole game is through in two hours, that there is only one weapon, most bosses can be beat within minutes without much effort, and every "dungeon" consists of about eight screens. What truly bothers me is that the game doesn't seem to have much substance overall. The visual baseline is cute, and the story idea funny. However, with the main character rudely ripping up every document they find, and burping at every found heart, I simply find too much strange and unappetizing contrast in the Turnip Boy.

135698389.review:
Don't waste your time on this one. It's a bunch of self referential, meme and pun humor that would only appeal to a 10 year old. Throw in a smattering of anti-capitalist rhetoric (money is bad right guys??) and you get a boring game devoid of any actual gameplay. you just walk around and do the next thing, but it's hilarious because there's a sign right beside the thing that tells you what to do, and they referenced that game you played.
This is the kind of thing you should get for free on a flash site from 2015, not something you have to pay for. The memes and game references just make it feel dated. (It's dangerous to grow alone... so funny because you're a turnip, right?)

I have no idea why people are comparing it to Zelda. The only thing it has in common with Zelda is the birds eye view and the fact that you use a sword. The gameplay is nothing like zelda in any way.

Just avoid it, not worth wasting your time on. Go play something like PIkuniku if you want a laid back, humorous adventure.

If you absolutely have to experience this game just watch someone play it on youtube, you will get the exact same experience but even better because you can fast forward through the absolute slog of "gameplay" it has.

135413059.review: TLDR: Its simpler and shorter than id like and i think i could've watched a letsplay for free and been just as happyPositives- The art is beautiful and adorable. It matches the expected aesthetic and goes well as a mirror to the games darker undertones- The main section of the story is simple but enjoyable and the side quests don't feel like they take you out of that main story too much and actually compliment it quite well- The lore is nicely woven into the story so its not to difficult to understand the context behind the world but its also not given in huge lore dumps or exposed in large pieces of written textNegatives- You can't rebind buttons for a controller and the game clearly works best on controller.- Its too short and honestly a bit too straight forward. I'd be more mad if I didn't get it on sale but it only took a few hours of casual game play to get all the achievements and hats not related to the train. I was hoping for a much longer story with more to do or at least a more satisfying ending :/ The train feels like an add on they slapped in there once they realized the game was too short or something just to pad out the game play time.- The boss fights are actually pretty basic and don't provide much of a challenge. I saw the name of this game and bought it instantly. 

I did not look at reviews. I barely looked at the screenshots. The name was enough to sell me.

I do not regret my purchase of this game.

Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a "Zelda clone" but that's not a bad thing whatsoever. The visual style is charmingly retro with a comic book-esque spin that I welcomed with open arms.

 The story is very "Saturday morning cartoon" yet it never felt boring. The characters were all funny and engaging in their own ways, with plenty of funny Easter eggs and references thrown in. The writing in this game is witty and really doesn't take itself seriously at all. Overall, a very relaxing story to kick back to on an evening!

This game is pretty short, clocking in at around 3 hours, BUT WAIT!

There's more-

The DLC for this game is a rogue-like with a LOAD more content,, there are more hats and things to unlock so I will be going back for seconds c:< 
There's a shocking amount of content here and, in my opinion, is fully worth paying full price for!

The bosses in this game are really fun and some are fairly challenging, offering a healthy dose of punch to an experience that you think would be relatively easy. This doesn't make the game overbearingly difficult however, as there are accessibility options you can tweak to play the way you want to and VERY generous checkpoints littered throughout :)
Enemy variety in this game is pretty vast and it was nice to see very obvious love put into crafting this game's world.

10/10 - Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a very very fun game where you commit tax evasion. What else do you want from me?

134674457.review:
Half a game with horrendous grammar.  Graphically, it's fine, to a point I'd even argue it looks really nice, but the game never really picks up.  The enemies are very basic, with limited mobility and simplistic AI of simply following the player, pacing back and forth in a straight line, or a few other simple actions from a few other simplistic enemy types.  The bosses run on patterns and are fine, they're not some RNG hellscape, but there's also very few of them.

There's almost no combat in the game, it's mostly just walking around, speaking to people,  and solving simplistic puzzles.  Initially, I thought the first dungeon in the game was intended as a tutorial dungeon, then it'd pick up, but it never really did.  There's a small moment at the end where it combined the puzzles you learn to do in each dungeon throughout the game, but when there's only a few of those, it's really short and unsatisfying.

The most interesting part of the game is already displayed within the trailer for it, wherein it shows the bosses and some of the wit of the dialogue, but that trailer really does give away the majority of the game.  The regular enemies aren't interesting to deal with, they're not satisfying, and they feel incomplete, like a high school student's project.  The first trailer visible on Steam, as of the time of my writing this, only shows gameplay of the train ride you unlock at the end of the game, but more on that later.  The second trailer shows some of the gameplay of other portions of the game, but I highly suggest you look up some gameplay videos without commentary to see how dull it actually is, since trailers can be edited in a way which makes the product look far more interesting than it really is.

As for the dialogue, it's ruined by the aforementioned poor grammar.  Commas are frequently missed or misplaced and there was even an instance where "it's" was used in place of "its" to show possession.  "It's" is ALWAYS a contraction, either of the formal "it is", or of the the informal "it has"; "it" plus the second word, with a portion cut out, the two jammed together, then a marker placed to indicate there's been an alteration and combination.  However, there was only a single instance of the incorrect its/it's use, but it still suggests a lack of care in the grammar and proof-reading.

Even if you ignore the pathetic grammar, you'll have to read through the dialogue of everyone you come across if you wish to progress through the game.  Your job is relegated to speaking to someone, speaking to someone else, speaking to someone else, and so on, acting as a liaison between people so as to receive some object in order to continue onto the next dungeon.  Along the way, you'll also need to look for a bunch of random papers to rip up.  If you find 100% of the papers to rip up, you then unlock the second form of the final boss, but even it feels shallow and unsatisfying.  When you defeat the final boss, no matter which form you end the game on, since the game ends after defeating the first form if you didn't find all of those papers, you're forced to sit through minutes of end credits, with no ability to speed up or skip them, even if it's your second time through them.

After completing the game, you unlock a train ride, but that train ride is nothing but endless fights against monsters with increasing difficulty.  However, this train is the most interesting part of the game, and it's a massive shame that they didn't decide to expand the game's world and create far more dungeons while combining the concepts from the train into the rest of the game.  After every boss you defeat in the train, you're allowed to choose an upgrade which boosts your abilities, but only while within the train.  Had they used those boosts from the train and added far more dungeons with greater complexity, better puzzles, more enemies, and the use of combinations of puzzles as the game progressed which slowly grew in complexity, then the game could've potentially been something enjoyable.

Unfortunately, this game is just another failed "Zelda" clone, and for an overinflated price that's nowhere near worth the cost.  At most, and it'd still be hard to suggest it even at this amount, the game should cost $5.  If you want to waste your time with it, get it on sale for $5 or less.  Otherwise, spend a little more and get something that's actually good, something that's actually worth it, something like "Rogue Heroes: Ruins of Tasos".  If you aren't certain about the one I've now suggested, go ahead and try its demo and see for yourself, just make sure to avoid this game.

Las principales causas de la guerra de Malvinas fueron las siguientes:

La usurpación de las Malvinas por Gran Bretaña en 1833. La Argentina había tomado posesión efectiva de las islas en 1820, mediante la designación de un gobernador y el envío una guarnición militar. Luego de la usurpación, el gobierno del primer ministro Charles Grey declaró las islas como parte del Imperio británico.

La decisión de las Naciones Unidas de tratar el caso de las islas Malvinas en el marco del Comité de Descolonización. Desde 1945 hubo varias resoluciones de la ONU que consideraron a las Malvinas, las Sandwich y las Georgias del Sur como territorios en litigio.
La «crisis de los chatarreros», como se llamó al incidente protagonizado por 41 trabajadores argentinos contratados para desmantelar instalaciones balleneras abandonadas en las islas Georgias del Sur. El 19 de marzo, los chatarreros izaron la bandera argentina, lo que provocó la reacción de Gran Bretaña, que envío dos buques para obligar a los operarios a arriar la bandera.
La decisión del presidente de facto argentino, Leopoldo Fortunato Galtieri, de invadir las islas para ganar popularidad y perpetuar en el poder a la última dictadura militar.
La férrea postura de la primera ministra británica Margaret Thatcher de no aceptar la pérdida de las islas y de utilizar el conflicto para fortalecer su gobierno, que estaba debilitado por la oposición de los sindicatos y parte de la población a su política de reformas neoliberales.
El apoyo dado por el presidente de los Estados Unidos, Ronald Reagan, a la decisión de Gran Bretaña de recuperar las islas. Además de amigos personales, Reagan y Thatcher eran los dos grandes líderes conservadores de principios de la década de 1980.
Lo erróneos que resultaron los dos supuestos sobre los que Galtieri y la Junta Militar decidieron el intento de recuperación de las islas Malvinas: que el Reino Unido limitaría su reacción al terreno diplomático y que los Estados Unidos no permitirían una escalada militar del conflicto.

134365436.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a game that very pleasantly surprised me. 

I bought it as I'm a fan of 2D Zelda games and TBCTE certainly takes after them. It follows the same general formula of finding new items and using them to complete dungeons. The game doesn't change said formula, but it may very well be for the better. Sometimes I just want to play a simple game and have some fun. The game is pretty easy - no puzzles are too difficult, but some of the later ones do require a bit of thinking. The combat is also simple, but the last few bosses do pose quite a challenge. Whilst I have died a few times, I never felt frustrated over my deaths.

Next, the story and the writing. The premise is simple - you are a Turnip that commits tax evasion. While a lot is obvious from the start, TBCTE surprised me with a few twists. You can also find many documents that tell many interesting stories. Overall, the game's lore is deeper than it seems at a first glance. As for the writing, the game doesn't take itself very seriously. You'll come across many jokes, some funny, some not. While not everyone might find the puns, references and 4th wall breaks funny, you can still enjoy the experience without them.

As for the soundtrack, that was probably the biggest surprise for me. Most of the OST is the generic music I expected from a game like this. It's not bad, but it wasn't great either. It simply did it's job well. However, later in the game, I was genuinely shocked by how good some tracks were, such as "Mutation", "Vidalia" and "Turnip Boy Go".

In terms of collectibles - there are two types. One unlocks a secret boss and the other one new outfits. Both are simple to find as long as you look around and talk to some NPCs. After beating the final boss, you can load to just before entering the final dungeon, so there are no missable achievements. Beating the game also unlocks an NPC that tells you hints on where to find the missing items.

Speaking of post game, there are only two things that you unlock - one is the previously mentioned NPC and the other is the endless battle dungeon. Neither are amazing, but the battle dungeon can extend the game's length a bit.

I only have one gripe with the game - how short it is. I got all achievements in about 2 hours and the game doesn't have a lot of replayability. TBCTE is pretty fun, so it's a shame how short it is. The price is a bit too high something so short. I heavily recommend buying it either on sale or as a part of a bundle.

To sum up, Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a short but great game with great humour, nice story, gameplay, artstyle and OST. If you like 2D Zelda games, you will enjoy this hidden gem. I will be patiently awaiting the sequel. That's all I have to say and remember - you don't have to pay taxes if the IRS can't catch you!

I enjoyed the game, and I was able to play it and finished it on my day off, so I don't support the bad reviews, but I do hope there is more content added. 134333278.review:
Game was pretty fun, a lot of running around the map which was a bit annoying but still very cute and fun to play through. I liked the story and the character design was adorable. 

It was a short game (took 3 hours total) but would have been even shorter if you didn't have to run from one end of the map to the other all the time. There's also a lot of dungeon puzzles that you have to make your way through which are fun the first time around but then you have to remember where to turn when coming back to complete the story. 

I also finished 90% of the story in about two hours (which included me exploring every inch of the map and interacting with all the npcs as well as doing the actual storyline) and then came back to it a week or two later to finish the game; I had forgotten what I was supposed to be doing and ran around interacting with npcs because I was trying to figure out what I was supposed to be doing. Eventually I had to research what to do which also took me a while to figure out because there's no map in the game so you have to run around looking for people scattered around the map completely from memory. 

Don't get me wrong it's still an adorable, fun game that definitely made me laugh out loud a couple times but there's a few things that were just annoying while I was playing. Still glad I finished it and would definitely recommend if you're interested in a short but cute story with some boss fights and lots of puzzles.

134073414.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a delightful game that offers a refreshing and unique gameplay experience. As the name suggests, the game follows the story of a turnip who decides to evade taxes, and it does so in a humorous and quirky way.

One of the best things about the game is its art style, which is charming and whimsical, and it perfectly complements the game's offbeat sense of humor. The game's soundtrack is also fantastic, with catchy and upbeat tunes that enhance the overall gameplay experience.

The gameplay itself is engaging and offers a good mix of puzzle-solving, combat, and exploration. The game's world is filled with interesting characters and locations to explore, and there are plenty of secrets and hidden areas to discover. The game also features multiple endings, which adds to its replayability.

Another great feature of the game is the sense of humor that permeates throughout. The game's writing is witty and clever, and it's sure to put a smile on your face. The various characters you encounter throughout the game are all unique and memorable, and their interactions with Turnip Boy are often hilarious.

Overall, Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a must-play for anyone looking for a fun and lighthearted gaming experience. Its unique premise, charming art style, engaging gameplay, and witty humor make it one of the most enjoyable games in recent memory. Whether you're a fan of indie games or just looking for something different, this game is well worth your time and attention.

133955410.review:
So... this game is kind of horrendous.
The combat is very easy, shallow, and unsatisfying.
All of the enemies and bosses are very easy and lack any sort of flair.
All of the puzzles are very easy and simple. The solutions are immediately obvious and require zero thought.
There's an awful lot of backtracking for such a small and short game. And it's not a fun sort of backtracking like in a metroidvania or survival horror, it's just walking between NPCs and giving them items.
The visuals are overall competent, the sprites are clean, but nothing about it is remarkable. There were no interesting visual setpieces at any point. I've played games that are literal scribbles that are much more visually striking. You get an awful lot of hats but all of them are worse than the default sprite.
The music is... intentionally bad? I think? It was ear-bleeding at any rate.
The writing is terrible. Bad uninventive plot, unfunny dialogue full of immediately dated references. It's really riding on the mildly odd title. But it's not like you spend the game finding creative ways to evade taxes, the tax evasion happens right at the start and then it stops mattering, it's just a sequence of random fetch quests.
The length is just under two hours, and that includes doing every single optional fetch quest.
I hate to be this negative but there is really not much to like about this game, and yet it's so highly rated.
The entire thing gives the air of "it's bad on purpose you guys", but even bad games are often interesting, this is not.
Not even remotely worth $15, I wouldn't even say it's worth $6 on sale.

133881519.review:
TL/DR at the bottom, checklist review after paragraph.

This is honestly a really fun, cute, and quirky game if you like pretty simple mechanics. It has a pretty funny story line that is sure to make you chuckle. Besides, who wouldn't like a cute little turnip that never speaks but loves to commit tax evasion? The graphics are pretty basic, but it looks visually pretty for the style of game that it is. Audio is nice, simplistic background ambiance that is pleasant to listen to. Sure, you might tone it out after a while, but it's definitely not something you feel compelled to mute while playing the game. The game mechanics are pretty simple and easy to do. Some of the boss battles are a tad on the challenging side, but nothing that can't be completed with a little bit of practice. When it comes to the steam achievements, they are completely achievable! One hidden achievement in particular gave me a run for my money, but I reckon it's probably more due to my skill level than actual difficulty. I would highly recommend this game, and think that you get a good amount of fun game play for a price point that is just right.

I do not get the appeal of this game. The gameplay consists of 1.5 hours of the following loop:
- Talk to NPCs until one asks you to find a thing
- Walk across the map to find the thing
- Walk back to deliver the thing
- While walking you may have to hit hopelessly non-threatening enemies with a stick until they die
- Repeat

Each step in this process is tedious rather than fun. Talking is tedious, scrolling through rambling, uninteresting, unhelpful dialog. Walking is tedious, you move at a slow crawl with no real movement abilities. Combat is tedious and unchallenging, with a single slow attack that easily dispatches even the bosses.

Maybe I'm missing something.

133784365.review:
I'm gonna be honest, I would have never known about this game had it not been for one of my kids who I work with had told me about it. He said it was a short and silly adventure game and I would like it. Lucky for me, it was on sale and I gave it a try.

You play as Turnip Boy and just as the title suggests, the game starts with you not paying your taxes and losing your greenhouse home to Mayor Onion. The only way to get it back is to become his assistant and do strange tasks for him in order to win your home back. Well, let's get to work!

This game is fairly simple and has a lot of meme-y writing. Lots of puns, 4th wall breaks, etc. I don't mind it and found myself chuckling at some of the jokes. In the beginning, all you can do is dodge roll and talk to the inhabitants of the world who are also vegetables and fruits. As you progress, you will be able to use plants that make bombs, a sword, and other fun doodads. The gameplay was never too hard and I had fun solving some of the puzzles too.

Just like classic adventure game fashion, there are collectibles you can find in the game as well. Hilariously and fascinatingly, they are documents that expand the story and give the game a deep story for those who are interested. It's hilarious that Turnip Boy just rips them all up, but you'll need them to get the true ending of the game. There are also side quests you can do and lots of equippable hats to customize your look. For a game so simple, it surprised me with its depth.

Lastly, once you finish the game you unlock two things. One is a survival train mode. You can play on a train level that has you fighting old and new enemies to see how far you can get. There are new collectibles and goodies for you to unlock as you play it for those who just want a lil more Turnip Boy. Also, you unlock an NPC who gives you hints on where to find the missing document collectibles so you can unlock the true ending. I super appreciated that one since on my playthrough I was only missing one and it helped me find it quickly to do the hidden final boss (which was sooo worth it).

Gripes? I have none honestly. The game is short, yes, but honestly, that is its charm. You can finish it in about 3ish hours and you'll feel satisfied. I left this game smiling and really enjoyed the comedy as well as the gameplay. There was never a boss that was too hard to beat. If I lost, it was because I wasn't playing cautiously enough, and I didn't encounter any bugs or glitches. All and all, this was a short and sweet package.

Final verdict? If you're looking for a short adventure game, this is perfect. Very fun and doesn't take up too much of your time. Has some nice bonus content if you wanna play a lil more and even has a surprisingly deep story if you want one too. I have to say, I'm looking forward to the sequel, Turnip Boy Robs a Bank to see more of this team's work. Thanks for reading!

133712919.review:
This game is way over-hyped. I really fail to see the appeal of this game

1. There is no meaningful story

No characters have any meaningful development. There are no plot developments that are worth any real consideration. Turnip boy doesn't talk. Any 'dialogue' is just one-sided exposition or bad humor

2. The gameplay is boring.

The puzzles are simple and the combat is just unfun. You are locked in place when you attack which feels awful. It's one thing in souls-like games where long attack animations force you to be more methodical about your approach to combat, but in this game it just makes the game feel clunky. The game isn't hard and the gameplay isn't satisfying enough to justify self-imposed challenge like a 'no-hit run'

3. The comedy is asanine

One could argue that the game's charm is in its 'comedy' but I find it to be asinine. The whole 'committing tax evasion' thing is just a gag and is only really funny the first time due to its novelty. I imagine the humor works something like the Borderlands series where it has a specific tone it shoots for and it either lands or misses horribly. I find myself in the latter camp


The one saving grace is how short it is. It actually felt like a chore getting through this game. If it was any longer I would have just dropped the game. There are literally HUNDREDS of games out there at the same pricetag or lower which are more worth your time. In this day and age where the indie games market is so saturated, I don't think this game is worth your time or your money.

TLDR: KEYBOARD/MOUSE DOESN'T WORK - still fun and enjoyable.

Graphics:
Adorable pixel art.

Storyline:
Cinema quality tax evasion.

Price:
Get it on sale. Please don't pay full price.
I played more than just the main story and also collected everything I could... and I have 3 hours. That's $5 per hour of gameplay... just abysmal.

Difficulty:
Extremely easy. Little to no challenge, even in boss fights.

AI:
They move towards you.

Cutscenes:
The "cutscenes" are just text box story progression.

Fun:
It's amazing! The combat is simple and intuitive, paired with small puzzles. It'll take you a second to figure out, never frustrating you but keeping you entertained.

Sounds/Music:
Arguably the best part. All the music in the game fits the art style perfectly, making it only more enjoyable to play.

Achievements:
You will not get all achievements by completing the main storyline/collecting all items.

Replayability:
Main story will probably not be fun to play through again. It has an endless brawler mode (think Archero) which may be fun, but it's far from the main purpose of the game.

Controls:
The game doesn't seem to support keyboard and mouse. I had to go find an old xbox 360 controller to play the game, but it was still enjoyable.

Performance:
Will run on anything.

Modding:
None

Selling Out:
There's a sequel coming soon, but that's not really selling out.

Similar Games:
- Minit

Bugs:
- I saw none

130874707.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion es un videojuego independiente con una premisa hilarante y original. En este juego, el jugador asume el papel de un nabo antropomórfico llamado Turnip Boy, que se encuentra en problemas con el gobierno del juego por no pagar sus impuestos.

A lo largo del juego, los jugadores deben explorar un mundo lleno de verduras animadas, resolver acertijos y luchar contra jefes desafiantes. La mecánica de juego se siente similar a la del popular juego Forager, pero con una torcedura única de corrupción de verduras y un toque de humor que hace que el juego se sienta fresco y emocionante.

Los gráficos del juego son impresionantes, con cada verdura animada de una manera divertida y única. La música también es excelente, con una banda sonora pegajosa y bien hecha que se ajusta perfectamente a la atmósfera general del juego.

En resumen, Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion es un juego divertido y original que seguramente te hará reír. Si estás buscando un juego de aventuras y puzles con una premisa única y mecánicas de juego emocionantes, ¡definitivamente deberías darle una oportunidad a este juego!

130571121.review:
It has its moments, but I personally wouldn't recommend it too highly.

Before playing this game, the main appeal to me was the humour and dialogue based on that ingenious title (I mean who doesn't find themselves instantly hooked with a name like "Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion"?). However most of that humour is very much related to current memes/ pop-culture, which is already starting to feel dated. It did catch me off-guard at some points and got a laugh now and then, but more often than not it had me feeling tired of the memes/ references.

Visually speaking it has some simple yet fun designs, and in terms of gameplay it's a pretty standard 2D Legend of Zelda style dungeon crawler, packed with a bunch of fetch quests. It's fairly competent and well polished, with no game-breaking bugs or awkward controls, but it just didn't hold my interest. I can't say whether it gets better later on since I only played through 2 or 3 of the dungeons, but I didn't really feel much of a challenge, and there just wasn't enough else to keep me motivated to keep playing.

130316169.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a cute and humorous puzzle-adventure game in which you play as Turnip Boy, a young turnip who finds himself in trouble with the law after failing to pay his taxes. The game is set in a world inhabited by vegetables and other plant-like creatures, and features a colorful cast of characters and a charming art style.

As you progress through the game, you'll need to solve puzzles, interact with characters, and avoid getting caught by the authorities as you try to pay off your debt and clear your name. The game has received generally positive reviews for its engaging gameplay, quirky sense of humor, and charming visual style.

One personal story that comes to mind is the time I got lost in a foreign city while traveling alone. It was a hot summer day and I was visiting a new place for the first time. I was feeling adventurous and decided to explore the city on my own, without a map or a tour guide.

Everything was going well until I turned down a small side street and suddenly realized that I had no idea where I was. I didn't recognize any of the buildings or landmarks, and my phone was running low on battery so I couldn't use it to look up directions.

I started to feel panicked and unsure of what to do. But then I remembered something my mom had told me: "If you ever get lost, just stay calm and try to retrace your steps. You'll figure it out."

I took a deep breath and tried to calm my nerves. Then, I started walking back the way I came, slowly and carefully, paying attention to the turns I had taken and the places I had passed. It took a while, but eventually I recognized a familiar street corner and knew I was headed in the right direction.

I made it back to my hotel safe and sound, and from then on I always made sure to have a map and a fully charged phone with me when I traveled. The experience taught me the importance of being prepared and staying calm in stressful situations.

As someone who has experienced the feeling of being lost and unsure of what to do, I can relate to Turnip Boy's predicament in the game. In my own personal experience, I got lost in a foreign city while traveling alone and had to rely on my wits and my sense of direction to find my way back to my hotel. It was a scary and stressful situation, but I learned the importance of staying calm and trying to retrace my steps. Similarly, in Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion, players must keep a cool head and use their problem-solving skills to navigate their way through the game and resolve Turnip Boy's legal issues.

130096817.review:
Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is filled with nonsensical humor and outdated memes and I loved every single second of it. With such a outlandish title, I bought this out of pure impulse and found myself a clever Zelda-Style game. The game has beautiful and colorful 32-bit art style that just fits what a Zelda-Like game is and the portraits during any cutscene and dialogues are adorable and well drawn.

You play as Turnip Boy, you inherited your grandfather's home but the Mayor inform you that you need to pay your taxes or else. Well our adorable little root vegetable decided that taxation is theft and ripped the paper right in front of the Mayor. Now you go on a wacky adventure as a wanted turnip against the tyrannical vegetable government all so you don't have to pay property taxes.

Storywise, you're simply avoiding taxes that ends up with you with doing various tasks and assisting various other vegetables in town. The "story" takes a backseat as you simply enjoy the interactions and humor the game throws at you. However, as you play through the main story, this cute game actually have quite a dark lore that caught me by surprise. The more you progress through the story, the more layers you unravel about the world of Turnip Boy. Trust me, the ice berg goes deep in this game.

The character interactions are the highlight of the game. If you're familiar with a lot of early 2000s to 2010s internet humor, then you will know what to expect. There are a lot of dated/ reference humors to the internet culture of the past that are actually executed pretty well. The humors are entertaining enough to get a chuckle or amusement out of you but never overstays its welcome. Every veggie you meet in the game are fun characters. While many characters are one note characters, their design and personalities are so varied and vibrant that you can't help but to like the majority of them.

Gameplay wise, you have light combat and a lot of running around doing chores for other vegetables. Combat is very similar to The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past. You see the world in a oblique eagle-eye view and you can move in any direction. There is a button to swing your weapon and a button to roll/dodge/interact. Very simple controls but it provides a good amount of engagement. The controls are very responsive so there was never a point in the game where I felt frustrated or felt like the game was unfair due to the controls. (Note that the game isn't really difficult unless you decide to play the optional rogue-like mode). The majority of the game, like past Zelda games, simply have you talking to folks and running errands for them that will lead you to new parts of the map. This is the best part of the game as this lets you explore the world and personalities that reside in it. Oh and you can collect different kind of hats/ stuff to put on Turnip Boy's head. Its great. I made my Turnip Boy bald.

Finishing the game in just 3 hours, the game is not long at all but enjoyable and memorable nonetheless. The only gripes I have of the game is I wish some of the darker backstories/lore was explored a bit more before reaching the conclusion but maybe my answers will be met in the upcoming sequel "Turnip Boy Robs a Bank". Overall, Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion just oozes charm throughout the whole game and is a simple enough game for any casual or hardcore gamer to just pick up and enjoy the ride. As soon as you lay eyes on Turnip Boy's smile in game, you'll be hooked immediately. If you can not justify yourself buying a 3 hour game for the full price of $15, then I highly suggest you grab this game on sale.

130082121.review:

Overall, I enjoyed my time with Turnip Boy. If I'd paid full price for it I probably would've felt a bit shortchanged given how I saw the credits in under 90 minutes & managed to 100% the game (with one RNG achievement) in under 3 hours, but on discount? Absolutely give it a shot!

Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion is a solid game with around 3hrs of gameplay to get 100% but has a decent replay value. 

The art direction is the best part of the game, everything is full of vibrant colors, bouncy energy an full of life.

The story is solid, having a fun adventure with traces of a deeper darker story behind the scenes and some genuinely shocking moments, the writing is funny and clever and has a very unique and charming quality to it that matches the game personality pretty well.

The gameplay is pretty simple, maybe you'll need to rethink a puzzle or two but you will never really get stuck at one, which in this case is great since the energy of the game makes you want to keep moving forward pretty quick. The fighting system is easy to get a hand on, the bosses are all really fun to fight and learn the patters on, but once you get the shovel and start spamming it the they all become really really easy, for your own fun i'd advise to just not spam attacks.

If you look carefully and talk to everyone, you'll probably get everything in one run, however if you dont theres no need to look up a guide, the game has a hint system that allows you to get what you missed.

Its overall a good game, specially with the rougelike minigame the game gets a lot more replay value, i would recommend you buy it and try it out for yourself

I play games as a form of entertainment - the value of which is proportional to the magnitude of fun, duration of that fun against the cost of that fun.

The graphics are cute.
The script is cute - not impressive, but mildly enjoyable.

Seeing the reviews being overwhelming positive, I figured this was a must play. 

Turns out, this must be a kids game, as it's far too simplistic, far too short. 

You just go around and bop things once or twice with a weapon - along with a handful of other mechanics that can largely be ignored if you just bop decently.  Only a handful of different opponents - almost all pose almost no challenge.  And collect hats.

For a $5.00 retail, I wouldn't give a negative review, but due to beating the game in a couple hours and almost no replay value, at $15.00 that's about $7.50 an hour, which isn't terrible, but there's far better value out there.

128867398.review: Turnip Boy is one of the most fun games I've played in a while. With a delightful art-style, fun and humourous dialogue, engaging gameplay that was uncomplicated but still challenging at times, and an incredible soundtrack. While the gameplay is a bit reminiscent of soulsbourne, it is much less difficult and less punishing, so highly recommend this game for less experienced players who want to up their skill level. Nevertheless I can recommend it for all skill levels still.

128835954.review:
This was a very cute and fun Zelda-like that you can easily beat and get all the achievements for within three or so hours!


+++ The graphics are smooth and well done. Everything has a slightly wobbly quality to it, but mostly due to leaning very much into a cute aesthetic. I admired how they didn't fall back on an 8-bit style, but rather a polished 16-bit one.

+++ Humorous and quirky interactions with NPCs, lots of offbeat humour, and quite a few pop culture references without obnoxiously overloading the player with them. If you get the references, then you get them, otherwise you still enjoy the whimsical atmosphere.

+++ The story starts out cute and has you fetch items and run around back and forth. Then it takes a strange detour partway through until the end. However, it still remains generally playful and light-hearted for the most part until the end. The recurring allusions to taxes and fighting the system are used to humorous effect.

++ The music is pretty good! Upbeat, happy tunes for the most part...and appropriate atmospheric music for the rest.

+ If you love collecting hats, you'll love the post-game. Thankfully, they're not linked to achievements so you can safely extend your experience without worrying about grinding towards them.

- I only died about thrice in the entire game, mostly wihiin some of the latter half's boss battles, but only because there were more mechanics to initially trial and error through simultaneously. Otherwise, there is absolutely NO penalty to dying and you can easily retry instantly after understanding what to do from the first time.

+/- The game is very short and is great to consume in one go in an afternoon/evening. The post game content is optional and not terribly difficult, although it still presents a little jump up in difficulty from the main game.

_____
In conclusion, definitely snatch up this game if it's on sale and you don't mind the length. 
It is very well worth the price for the whole package if you're looking for a compact unique experience for a lazy afternoon/evening in.

Look for something else if you want a longer experience to revisit for days to come.
