128421431.review:
This game is unfunny trash. It's just memes and the bosses are all block pushing puzzles. It wants you to make Zelda comparisons but it's closer to old free flash games. These developers are too inexperienced to be charging for their game.

1. Half the game is backtracking. The worst kind. Walking around rooms you already walked around before just to talk to an NPC because another NPC told you to talk to them. As far as I can tell the game isn't joking, so the devs probably don't know that this kind of padding is boring to play through.
2. The game has three buttons dedicated to three items... Not in the obvious way anything with common sense would have it work, two of the button switch the items, and one uses it.
3. It tries to be dark at times, and by dark I mean ripping off Adventure Time. It doesn't do anything differently than Adventure Time, it's just a few bits of lore from it without adding anything. It also does the Pokemon ghost thing except less. That's a good way to describe this game, just stealing things and cutting it down until you wonder why they bothered.
4. It's just streamer bait that was made when Yoshi Commits Tax Fraud was popular. This is the worst kind of game, the kind that was designed to be enjoyed by watching some screaming idiot laugh at every joke no matter how unfunny it is. The very foundation of this game is scummy.
5. This game has a rouge-like mode. It's two new bosses and the rest is filler. That's it. Why not just make the bosses? Why waste so much of my time? It doesn't have replay value.

This is not a game for people that like games. If you had any sense you'd skip this one. I would list some games that are better, but Zelda and the Lampshade of no real significance was better, so that would be a long list. Seriously, do not bother, even if you get it for free. Go play Evoland 2 or something.

128106958.review:
A cute little 3 hour or so adventure game, Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion starts you off mid tax evasion and having to work for the mayor doing his chores, puzzle solving and maybe some side quests in order to get your home back; leaning heavily in humor and references which include pop culture and social media.

The memes, while funny, do date the game and as the game gets older I'm sure a young player may be asking about the "What did you say to me you little Turnip?!" or other memes that have faded into obscurity. Even I didn't know what some of the memes were, leaving me thinking was this some kind of inside joke with the developers and not a meme per se. 
On the other hand the game has many options of how you play it, specifically an in game speed run timer, Godmode and damage options as well as daily challenges for after you have beaten the game.

Is Turnip Boy Commits Tax Evasion worth the $15 for a 3 hour story? Maybe not. On sale or bundled? probably. Either way I did enjoy the game, but the best time to play it is now and not in the future where you may need to Google the joke.

[b] CONCLUSIÓN [/b]

Turnip es un juego muy original con diversas mecánicas en juego. Hay rompecabezas fáciles (algunos un poco más rebuscados), misiones de ir para un lado hacia al otro hablando con los ciudadanos vegetales, enemigos simples, bosses que te rompen la tranquilidad, humor, referencias, sombreritos, muuuchos sombreritos y muchos papeles que romper. Me ha parecido un juegazo (comprado en oferta) y me ha durado unas 4 horas (unas 5 si quieres conseguir todos los logros). Tiene muchas cosas buenas a los que hacer referencia, como el estilo artístico, las mecánicas habladas con anterioridad, la fácil jugabilidad, el protagonista que manejamos está bien gracioso, los momentos en los que el juego rompe la 4ta pared, etc. Lo único malo que podría comentar es la bso, que se acaba haciendo un poco trillante y a parte, quizás también le hubiera metido un mapa para poder guiarte un poco al principio del juego, ya que tienes que ir a muchos sitios, el mapa es más o menos grande y puedes acabar dando bastantes vueltas. Aún así, juegardo 10/10 lo volvería a jugar. uwu
PD: no te sientas mal por romper algunos documentos, siempre piensa que te obligan. (Lo siento fresa, lo siento Jerry...)

127859528.review:
What an astonishing game. The main gameplay is essentially completing fetch quests by talking to everyone you meet, and a bit of combat. The quests are simple, the story is easily understandable, but what sets is apart is the writing.

When completing a quest you usually rip a document in half, starting with the tax bill, hence the game name. Later on this progresses to love letters, notices of military service, and countless random documents. Yes it's a basic gimmick, but other character's reactions to the senseless ripping is beautiful. Every character's dialog is pretty entertaining, and it's a great motivator for completing the next little quest.

The combat is relatively smooth, but nothing too new. Most of it is spent swapping between your melee weapon (used to inflict damage) and your watering can, used to grow helpful plants nearby. You're unlikely to die very often, but the boss fights take a lot of attention and patience to get through safely.
